data.title: 166 Things to Do in Philly This Week and Weekend
data.meta_description: Looking for things to do in Philadelphia? Find the best shows, events, festivals, concerts, things to do with kids, and happenings in Philly.
data.text:
Best of Philly’s 50th Anniversary bash! Plus, a spooky circus, a hearse festival, a Chappell Roan dance party, cat videos, a Swiftie fest, Olympics, and Mamma Mia!

Festivals, Food & Other Fun Stuff

OLYMPICS

Olympics Watch Parties, Specials and More

The Olympics run through August 11th with so much to see — and plenty of Philly-area athletes on Team USA. From themed food specials to watch parties and to photo ops and more, here are the best places to celebrate the Summer Olympics around Philadelphia.

OUTDOORS

The Oval

Philadelphia’s Favorite Traffic Island (seasonal category) is back, with a summertime slate of activities and attractions including a beer garden, food trucks, art installations, live music, movies, games and such. This week’s festivities include the all-day Hip Hop in the Park event curated by TAMEARTZ featuring music, dancing, graffiti, and more on Saturday. Performers include Reef the Lost Cauze, DJ Tony Touch, Large Professor, Skeme Richards, DJ JS1 and lots more. The Oval!

Free, continues through August 25th, in and around Eakins Oval, 2451 Benjamin Franklin Parkway.

See Also: What to Expect at the Oval Pop-Up on the Parkway This Summer

FOOD/FLOWERS

Peach & Sunflower Festival

Pick peaches and sunflowers at Shady Brook Farm’s annual selfie-inciting festival. Plus live music, wagon rides, go-carts, the giant jumping pillow, rubber ducky races and more.

$12-$15 for admission, through August 11th, Shady Brook Farm, 931 Stony Hill Road, Yardley.

FOOD/DRINK

PHS Pop-Up Gardens

Is it beer garden season, people. The Pennsylvania Horticultural Society hosts two pop-up gardens: on South Street and in Manayunk.

Pay as you go, through late fall; PHS Pop-Up Garden at Manayunk, 106 Jamestown Avenue; PHS Pop-Up Garden at South Street, 1438 South Street.

TOUR/ART

Summer aBroad Augmented Reality Tour

Use your smartphone to take an interactive tour of sites in and around North Broad Street, including the Rail Park, the Divine Lorraine Hotel, the Historic Blue Horizon, the Leon H. Sullivan Charitable trust and Sea Abroad Experience, the Historic Sullivan Progress Plaza and the Uptown Theater.

Free, through August 31st, North Broad Street.

FOOD

Ardmore Restaurant Week

This two-week restaurant week on the Main Line offer prix fixe menus for lunch and dinner (at $20 $30 and $40). Participating restaurants include Autana, Lu & Aug’s, Positano Ristorante, Twenty One Pips and more. Here’s the list of participating restaurants.

Pay as you go, through August 10th, multiple locations in Ardmore.

OUTDOORS/DINOSAURS

Summer of Dinos

Morris Arboretum is overrun with dinosaurs as well as Plants in the Age of Dinosaurs. Take a self-guided tour of the grounds and enjoy the outdoor miniature train is displays set 66-252 million years ago.

Included in $20 admission, through September 30th, Morris Arboretum, 100 East Northwestern Avenue.

BEER

Parks on Tap

This week, Parks & Rec’s traveling beer garden hauls its taps, tables and grills into the supple earth of Matthias Baldwin Park in ye old Franklin Town, on the site of the old Baldwin Locomotive Works. Some say on a quiet night you can still hear the chugga-chugga of ghost trains haunting the park, looking for souls to burn like coal.

Free till you spend money, August 7-11 p.m., Matthias Baldwin Park, 423 North 19th Street.

See Also: Philly’s Best Kid-Friendly Beer Gardens

LIGHTS

Philadelphia Chinese Lantern Festival

Every year, Franklin Square angers the ancient ones with this glorious and brazen display of electricity, which includes among its illuminated attractions a fiery 200-foot-long dragon. This is the year of the dragon, BTW. Besides the lantern displays, there’s juggling, acrobatics, dancing, music, food, a beer garden, mini-golf, a fountain show and more.

$25, through August 18th, 6-11 p.m. nightly, Franklin Square, 200 North 6th Street.

See Also: Your Guide to the Philadelphia Chinese Lantern Festival in Franklin Square

KIDS/FISH

Now Swimming @ Adventure Aquarium

SpongeBob SquarePants‘ 25th Anniversary Adventure Aquarium hosts an immersive “SpongeBob experience” including photo ops, an episode screening, worksheets and more. Through September 15th.

Shark Summer It’s hot shark summer, baby. Or cold, maybe? Point is, Adventure Aquarium has you covered with behind-the-scenes tours, the 81-foot suspended Shark Bridge, shark trivia, touchable sharks, and a visit from the magical Scuba Tooth Fairy who dives in among the sharks to scoop up teeth. What does she do with the teeth!? Through August 18th.

Included in $28-$48 admission, Adventure Aquarium, 1 Riverside Drive, Camden.

On Stage

THEATER

Mamma Mia!

An upbeat jukebox musical full of romance, paternity-test intrigue, and lots and lots of ABBA. The soundtrack includes “Dancing Queen,” “Take a Chance on Me,” “The Winner Takes It All,” and lots more.

$26-$145, August 6th-11th, Academy of Music, 240 South Broad Street.

MUSIC

Zach Bryan

The country music star’s Quittin’ Time tour stops by the Linc fir two shows this week (with Turnpike Troubadors and Levi Turner). Sound like it’s time to play Two Truths and a Lie!

Zach Bryan was born in Okinawa and raised in Oklahoma.

Zach Bryan has spoken out against transphobia.

Zach Bryan dueted with Kacey Musgraves on the number one hit “I Remember Everything,” a tribute to actress Marilu Henner, who famously has a photographic memory.

$390-$444, 7 p.m., August 6th and 7th, Lincoln Financial Field, 1 Lincoln Financial Field Way.

MUSIC

Goschenhoppen Folk Festival

Not “folk” like music, though there is some of that. The Goschenhoppen Folk Festival in Montgomery County features more than 500 volunteers in costume portraying 18th- and 19th-century Pennsylvania Germans, using period-appropriate tools, instruments, etc. “You will find yourself surrounded by the sights, sounds and smells of a day in Goschenhoppen.” Sounds delightful, and unusual, and not at all the start of an A24 folk-horror movie.

$15-$22; August 9th, noon to 8 p.m., and August 10th, 10 a.m.-6 p.m.; the Henry Antes Plantation 318 Colonial Road, Perkiomenville.

THEATER/PERFORMANCE

The Ghostly Circus: Black Box Paradox

The Fringe Bar hosts this multifaceted live show featuring “contemporary circus and flow arts,” sideshow, dance, theatrics, storytelling, magic and more. It sounds pretty freaky: “Black Box Paradox prompts us to think about the possible near future when most analytics will be outsourced to fully-automated semi-intelligent systems with their decision-making logic being mostly opaque to us.”

$35-$75, August 10th & 11th, 7-9 p.m., Fringe Bar, 140 North Columbus Boulevard.

THEATER

Grease

Bucks County Playhouse presents a new production of the beloved musical by Jim Jacobs and Warren Casey. Directed by Hunter Foster. Choreography by Alison Solomon. “Summer days drifting away, to uh, oh those summer nights.”

$32-$72, August 9th-September 8th, Bucks County Playhouse, 70 South Main Street, New Hope.

COMEDY

Philly’s Phunniest

The semifinals for Helium’s annual comedy competition continue this week. Here’s who’s playing when.

$15-$23, 7 p.m., through August 8th, Helium, 2031 Sansom Street.

COMEDY

Luenell

The veteran comedian is probably best known for her role in the first Borat movie. More recently, she’s turned up in Coming 2 America, Dolemite Is My Name, Hacks, It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia and John Mulaney’s Everybody’s in L.A.

$40-$75, August 8th & 9th, 6 p.m., City Winery, 990 Filbert Street.

COMEDY

Craig Shoemaker

The Mount Airy comic and actor plays a pair of shows in his hometown. Shoemaker has been in a lots of movies and shows over the years, from Scream 2 to Simon and Simon to Parks & Rec.

$27-$37, August 10th & 11th, 4 p.m., Helium, 2031 Sansom Street.

THEATER

A Midsummer Night’s Dream

Hedgerow Theatre Company partners with Mauckingbird Theatre for a reimagining of the Shakespeare classic full of humor, magic and young love, this time set at an elite boarding school. Directed by Peter Reynolds.

$35, through August 11, Hedgerow Theatre Company, 64 Rose Valley Road, Rose Valley.

THEATER

Somewhere Over the Border

This new “musical odyssey” by Brian Quijada takes cues from The Wizard of Oz in its story of a young woman making her way from El Salvador to the United States. “With onstage musicians weaving together cumbia, Mexican mariachi, boleros, American rock, and hip hop, up-and-coming writer and composer Brian Quijada honors his mother in a fantastically true tale of determination, family, and friendship.”

$47, through August 11th, People’s Light, 39 Conestoga Road, Malvern.

Movies

Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan

William Shatner, Leonard Nimoy, DeForest Kelley, Nichelle Nichols and the rest of the crew of the starship Enterprise star in this director’s cut of Nicholas Meyer’s 1982 space adventure about a freakishly buff Ricardo Montalban putting space weevils in people’s ears and … then I blacked out. But I’m still grateful to Aunt Sissy and Uncle Phillip for taking me to see this movie. Tagline: “Prepare yourself for Warp-10 excitement!” August 9th at 7 p.m., August 10th at 4 p.m. See Also:

Star Trek III: The Search for Spock (Leonard Nimoy, 1984). August 10th, 7 p.m.

Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home (Leonard Nimoy, 1984). August 10th, 9:30 p.m.

$15.50, Film Society Center, 1412 Chestnut Street.

Director Series: Lee Chang-Dong

Philadelphia Film Society presents screenings of several films by Oscar-nominated South Korean author-turned-director Lee Chang-Dong.

Poetry (2010) August 7th, 7 p.m.

Secret Sunshine (2007) August 8th at 7 p.m.; August 11th at 4 p.m.

Burning (2018) August 9th, 6:30 p.m.

$15.50, Film Society Center, 1412 Chestnut Street.

Free Outdoor Movies This Week

August 7th: 50 First Dates @ Libertee Grounds

August 7th: Star Wars: The Force Awakens @ Cira Green

August 8th: Dave @ Schuylkill Banks

August 8th: Jaws @ Historic Rittenhouse Town

August 8th: Kung Fu Panda 4 @ Mifflin Square Park

August 9th: Wonka @ The Oval

August 9th: Barbie @ Clark Park

August 10th: Spirited Away @ Cira Green

August 10th: Wish @ Thomas Hart Park

August 10th: Barbie @ McMichael Park

August 11th: The NeverEnding Story @ Spruce Street Harbor Park

Free, multiple locations.

See Also: Where to Watch Free Outdoor Movies in Philadelphia This Summer

50 Years in the Making

The Clay Studio continues its semicentennial celebration with this exhibition of works by 140 alumni from its resident artist, guest artist, and associate artist program.

Free, through September 1st, The Clay Studio, 1425 North American Street.

Dream House: Inside Music + Video

This group installation at Asian Arts Initiative sounds like a lot of fun. Dream House “highlights shifting roles of music video as a hybrid form of creative expression beyond their musical and cinematic quality as promotional tools of the music industry.” On monitors and TV screens, watch works by Alex Da Corte, Jordan Deal, Elle Hong, Maegan Houang, and more. Also, check out Zain Alam’s audio/video installation Meter & Light: Day. Plus, Dance Dance Revolution and karaoke in the lounge.

Through August 3rd, Asian Arts Initiative, 1219 Vine Street.

In Pursuit: Artists’ Perspectives on a Nation

The National Liberty Museum examines “the power of art as civic dialogue” in its latest multi-media group exhibition featuring sculptures and large-scale installations by Anila Quayyum Agha, Angel Cabrales, Nicholas Galanin, Arghavan Khosravi, Aram Han Sifuentes, Artur Silva, and Marisa Williamson.

Continues through October 28th. $12 museum admission, National Liberty Museum, 321 Chestnut Street.

Now Showing @ the Art Museum

Take a Seat: Understanding the Modern Chair — modern chairs from the permanent collection. Ongoing.

Expanded Painting in the 1960s and 1970s — radical innovations in painting by Alma Thomas, Sam Gilliam and more. Ongoing.

Collecting Japanese Art in Philadelphia — Drawn from the works highlighted in the new publication Art of Japan: Highlights from the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Ongoing.

Mythical Creatures: China and the World, explores diversity by comparing mythical creatures in different cultures. Through June 1st, 2025.

Mary Cassatt at Work — The PMA presents the first major showing of the Pennsylvania-born French Impressionist artist’s oeuvre since 1998-99. Through September 8th.

Seeing with Empathy: The Female Gaze in American Modernism, ongoing.

$14-$23 admission, Philadelphia Museum of Art, 2600 Benjamin Franklin Parkway.

John Jarboe: The Rose Garden

The trans artist presents “a multi-room domestic environment reimagining John’s gender journey.” The Rose Garden is an “immersive maze of memories and provocations” full of video sculptures, music, objects and more. Read more here. Through September 29th.

Free (suggested donation $5), Fabric Workshop and Museum, 1214 Arch Street.

Now Showing @ Michener Art Museum

George R. Anthonisen: Meditations on the Human Condition The Michener hosts a career-spanning exhibition of works by the accomplished sculptor, including 40 bronze sculptures, maquettes, and frescoes, inside and outside the museum. Through October 14th.

Monuments and Myths Subtitled The America of Sculptors Augustus Saint-Gaudens and Daniel Chester French, this new exhibition at Michener explores the artists’ “intersecting biographies and examines the affinities that made both of them leaders in their field.” Through January 5th.

$15 museum admission, Michener Art Museum, 138 South Pine Street, Doylestown.

Now Happening @ the Museum for Art in Wood

The Poetry Gumball Machine Project — Poet and “multiform artist” LindoYes, the project is more or less what it sounds like, a mechanized sculpture that dispenses poetry stuffed inside little walnut shell capsules. The PGMP will be on display at the Museum for Art in Wood through the rest of the year. Through December 31st.

Experiencing Form: Phil Brown and the Museum’s Residency Artist Alumni, group show. Through September 15th.

Fruition: Windgate Arts Residency Program in Wood 2024, The Museum for Art in Wood’s annual summer group exhibition includes works by Chance Coalter, Jamie Herman, Jodie Prud’homme, Sara Tabbert, Molly Nemer, Sarah Watlington, Brittany Rudolf, Folayemi Wilson and Melissa Engler. Through October 20th.

Free admission, Museum for Art in Wood, 141 North 3rd Street.

Imprint: Dox Thrash

Subtitled “Black Life, and American Culture,” this new exhibition at the African American Museum in Philadelphia invites visitors to “explore the life and artistic legacy” of Dox Thrash, who was a Buffalo Soldier and Black Vaudeville performer before he became a trailblazing Philly printmaker.

$10-$14, through August 4th, African American Museum in Philadelphia, 701 Arch Street.

Now Showing @ the Barnes

Matisse & Renoir: New Encounters at the Barnes — This new exhibition arranges 34 works by the boundary-pushing artists in a way that emphasizes their art-historical context. Runs through September 8th.

Education & Empowerment: Scholarship Recipients at the Barnes Foundation, 1927-1949 — Includes archival materials by Paul B. Moses, Ablyne Lockhart, Dr. DeHaven Hinkson and Aaron Douglas. Through August 15th.

Visions, group exhibition of works by artists from Mural Arts Philadelphia’s Guild program and SCI Phoenix. Through August 26th.

Museum admission is $23-$30, Barnes Foundation, 2025 Benjamin Franklin Parkway.

Entryways: Nontsikelelo Mutiti

The Zimbabwean-born visual artist and educator was invited to reimagine the windows on the ICA’s facade.

Free, through December 31st. Institute of Contemporary Art, 118 South 36th Street.

Every Leaf & Twig: Andrew Wyeth’s Botanical Imagination

The Brandywine Museum hosts this Andrew Wyeth exhibition focusing on “the fragile rhythms and intimate dramas of plant life,” and includes 40 watercolors and drawings, many of which have never been exhibited before. Through September 15th.

$18-$20, Brandywine Museum of Art, 1 Hoffman’s Mill Road, Chadds Ford.

Museums

Constructing Knowledge

Subtitled 300 Years of The Carpenters’ Company of the City and County of Philadelphia, this longterm exhibition at the Athenæum celebrates three centuries of bringing architects, contractors and engineers together like finely fitted joists. Now, you may be thinking: Are not Philadelphia the city and Philadelphia the county the same thing? Are they not, in a word, coterminous? Look, you wanna pick a fight with a 300-year-old gang of carpenters, that is your business. Leave me out of it.

Free, through August 30th, the Athenæum Of Philadelphia, 219 South 6th Street.

The Sweetest Side of Life: Swedish Candy & Confections

The Swedish Museum in FDR Park hosts this pop-up exhibition featuring “the collection of Tyler Graybeal, owner of Sweetish–Swedish Candy and Goods.” Googled it. He’s a real person! His collection includes tins, wrappers, bottles, postcards and more. Swedish sweets are available for sale, too.

$15 admission, through September 15th, American Swedish Historical Museum, 1900 Pattison Avenue.

Witness to Revolution: The Unlikely Travels of Washington’s Tent

This exhibition will “bring to life the stories of individuals from all walks of life who saved Washington’s tent from being lost over the generations and who ultimately fashioned this relic into a symbol of the fragile American republic.” Includes art, artifacts, rare documents and the tent itself.

Included in museum admission of $13-$22, through January 5th, Museum of the American Revolution, 101 South 3rd Street.

Now Happening @ the Academy of Natural Sciences

Under the Canopy: Animals of the Rainforest — This new special exhibit includes “interactive discovery stations, dynamic displays and engaging programming” surrounding the importance of rainforests and the plants and animals that live there. Through September 2nd.

Life Onto Land: The Devonian — An exhibition on the life and ecosystems of the Devonian period, the geological era during which creatures wriggled up on dry land, which everybody agrees was a solid move with a lot of potential. Through September 29th.

Bug Fest — A weekend of all things bugs, from scientists talks to roach races to a marketplace and beyond. August 10th-11th.

Included with museum admission of $21-$25, Academy of Natural Sciences, 1900 Benjamin Franklin Parkway.

The Doan Gang: Outlaws of the Revolution

The Mercer Museum’s immersive exhibition tells the story of Revolutionary War-era loyalists. “Learn how these local outlaws plotted, schemed, and plundered their way through a divided world in the earliest days of a budding American nation, and why their deep loyalty to British rule in the colonies made them enemies of the Founding Fathers.”

$15, through December 31st, Mercer Museum, 84 South Pine Street, Doylestown.

The Art of the Brick

The Franklin Institute presents this new long-running exhibition featuring a collection of “inspiring artwork” — bricked-up versions of Starry Night, Mona Lisa, etc. — made by LEGO master Nathan Sawaya. Plus a 9,000-square-foot brick play space.

$20-$43, through September 2nd, Franklin Institute, 222 North 20th Street.

Wild Kratts: Creature Power

At the Please Touch Museum, kids can tap into their “creature power” with a special exhibit based on the PBS series Wild Kratts. Little ones can investigate four different interactive habitats and learn about the animal world with games, movement and problem-solving.

$22, through September 1st, Please Touch Museum, 4231 Avenue of the Republic.

BOLD: Color from Test Tube to Textile

This new exhibition at Old City’s Science History Institute explores the complicated history and science of natural and synthetic dye-making “drawing on dye sample books, vivid clothing, and scientific instruments.” Through August.

Free admission, Science History Institute, 315 Chestnut Street.

Outdoors

Festival of Fountains

Flowers and greenery are usually the focus of a trip to Longwood Gardens, but this annual summer show is all about the waterworks. And the lights. And there’s some mood music, too. Timed admission tickets are required, so plan your visit ahead of time.

$32, continues through October 27th, Longwood Gardens, 1001 Longwood Road, Kennett Square.

Summerfest

There’s no roller-skating this summer, but there will be games of chance, mini-golf, a Ferris wheel, food, drinks and a nice view of the Delaware River to boot.

Pay as you go, ongoing, 101 South Christopher Columbus Boulevard.

Spruce Street Harbor Park

The lovely and popular Spruce Street Harbor Park returns for another summer of lights, hammocks and action along the Delaware. Also: food, drinks, ice cream, barges, chairs and a general feeling that we can have nice things.

Free unless you spend money, ongoing, 301 South Christopher Columbus Boulevard.

See Also: Your Guide to the Delaware Waterfront This Season

Andalusia Historic House, Gardens & Arboretum

The 50-acre historic estate along the Delaware River is open for self-guided tours of its formal gardens and native woodlands. Picnics encouraged.

$15, through November 8th, Andalusia Historic House & Gardens, 1237 State Road, Andalusia.

Click here to jump down to the weekend.

MONDAY, AUGUST 5th

MUSIC

Missy Elliott

Supported by Ciara, Busta Rhymes and Timbaland, hip-hop superstar Missy “Misdemeanor” Elliott’s first-ever headlining tour arrives at the Wells Fargo Center on Monday night. Sounds like it’s time to play Two Truths and a Lie!

Missy Elliott’s Out of This World tour’s sci-fi theme is enhanced by a multitude of screens, fireballs, backup dancers, costume changes and a platform flying over the stage.

Missy Elliott has had 10 top 10 hits including “Get Ur Freak On,” “Work It,” “1, 2 Step,” (With Ciara), and more.

Missy Elliott has never seen Halloween: Resurrection, and so may be unaware that one of her tour-mates roundhouse kicked Michael Myers in the face.

$79-$329, 7 p.m., Wells Fargo Center, 3601 South Broad Street.

COMEDY

Shane Gillis & Friends

After coming up through the Philly comedy scene, standup-podcaster Shane Gillis was famously added to/ejected from SNL in the span of five days back in 2019 (due to his offensive oeuvre). Gillis landed on his feet however, with several high profile gigs and shows, including hosting SNL last year, and a Netflix series called Tires. This week and next he’s bring some friends with him for a pair of Monday night shows at Helium.

Sold out, 7:30 p.m., Helium, 2031 Sansom Street.

MOVIES

Philadelphia Psychotronic Film Society

Watch “cult/weirdo/trash films” on the first and third Mondays of every month.

$5, 7:30 p.m., PhilaMOCA, 531 North 12th Street.

TUESDAY, AUGUST 6th

MUSIC

Die Spitz

This all-girl shoegaze grunge band from Austin does it loud and dramatic. Are they metal? They’re not metal unless Bleach was metal. Then they’re metal. And this video’s pretty metal. With Lying Season.

$15, 8 p.m., Foto Club, 3743 Frankford Avenue.

BOOKS

The Lost Boy of Santa Chionia

Author Juliet Grames is making two stops in the Philly area on Tuesday, in support of her new novel, The Lost Boy of Santa Chionia. “Set in the wild heart of Calabria, a land of sheer cliff faces, ancient tradition, dazzling sunlight—and one of the world’s most ruthless criminal syndicates—[the novel] is a suspenseful puzzle mystery, a captivating romance, and an affecting portrait of a young woman in search of a meaningful life.”

$60, includes lunch and a copy of the book, noon-2 p.m., Teresa’s Café, 124 North Wayne Avenue, Wayne. | Free, 7-8 p.m., in conversation with Jason Rekulak, Reads & Company, 234 Bridge Street, Phoenixville.

MUSIC

Family Underground

The long-running Denmark guitar/synth psych-drone duo released Fixed Doubles in March. Two songs, 31 minutes. Gonna go ahead a give a thumbs-up to mid-song pee breaks. Also on the bill: Philly acts Fursaxa & Heavenly Bodies.

$10-$20, 8-10:30 p.m., Pageant : Soloveev, 607 Bainbridge Street.

<a href="https://familyunderground.bandcamp.com/album/fixed-doubles">Fixed Doubles by Family Underground</a>

HAPPY HOUR

Fishtown Taps

It sure does. Enjoy drink specials at multiple bars and restaurants in the Fishtown District. Here’s a list of participating business and their specials.

Pay as you go, 5-7 p.m., Tuesdays, multiple locations in Fishtown.

MUSIC

DIIV

The NYC shoegaze band released its fourth record Frog in Boiling Water in May. Pitchfork gave it a 7.6 and called it “an anxious and sour record that copes with capitalism and its knock-on emotional effects.” With Horse Jumper of Love and Dutch Interior.

$30-$33, 8 p.m., Union Transfer, 1026 Spring Garden Street.

MUSIC

Kaitlin Butts

Rising country star Kaitlin Butts just dropped a catchy, delirious song (and video) called “Wild Juanita’s Cactus Juice” that’s halfway between a Hee-Haw sketch and a red dirt country version of “Funky Cold Medina.” Very flashy, very tongue-in-cheek. Ken Pomeroy opens her show at MilkBoy on Tuesday.

$20, 8 p.m., MilkBoy, 1100 Chestnut Street.

TALK/BOOKS

Take Care of Them Like My Own

Pediatric surgeon Dr. Ala Stanford discusses her new book — billed as part memoir, part manifesto — about the “devastating racial injustices in our healthcare system,” in conversation with Sheinelle Jones of NBC News/The Today Show.

$35-$200, 6 p.m., Commonwealth Plaza, Kimmel Center, 300 South Broad Street.

KIDS

Parkway Pals

Sister Cities Park brings back its Parkway Pals series of free weekly kids’ programming. On Tuesday mornings, the Free Library of Philadelphia brings Story Art — interactive story and craft time — and the Fabric Workshop and Museum will keep the creativity going with “Art Garden.”

Free, 10:30 a.m.-12:30 p.m., Sister Cities Park, 210 North 18th Street.

More Tuesday Stuff

MUSIC: Sleep House, with Jordan Dean, The Spins and Innlet. $14.93, 7:30 p.m., PhilaMOCA, 531 North 12th Street.

MUSIC: Rose Hotel, Pearla and Deerking. $12, 9 p.m., Ortlieb’s Lounge, 47 North 3rd Street.

STORYTELLING: The Moth Storyslam: Hot Mess. $17.50, 7:30 p.m., World Cafe Live, 3025 Walnut Street.

MUSIC: Five for Fighting, with Dan Orlando. $33, 7:30 p.m., Ardmore Music Hall, 23 East Lancaster Avenue.

WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 7th

Philadelphia Magazine’s 2024 Best of Philly Soirée Presented by Wells Fargo

It’s that time of year again! Philadelphia magazine’s Best of Philly issue is here, and not only are we toasting to a new class of BOP winners, we’re also celebrating our 50th anniversary of crowning Philly’s finest. We’ve got a list of over 45 of the city’s top culinary talents (including some of this year’s winners and previous years’ alums) all serving up tasty bites at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Hurry up and get your tickets already because you’re not going to want to miss this event.

$125, 6:30-9:30 p.m., Philadelphia Museum of Art, 2600 Benjamin Franklin Parkway.

MUSIC

Sophie Powers

Bolstered by intense rock-dance beats, unabashed autotune and chaotic NES punk backing tracks that call to mind a boardwalk arcade just minutes the singularity, this rising Toronto hyper-pop star splits her time between Comic Book Guy’s daydreams and the Snyder cut of Ready Player Three. I have no idea what I’m talking about. But your kids will love it. With Zoe Ko and Novul.

$15-$20, 8 p.m., World Cafe Live, 3025 Walnut Street.

HISTORY/CRAFTS

Reviving Germantown Yarns in the 21st Century

Courtney Kelley and Kate Gagnon Osborn, founders of Kelbourne Woolens, lead this lecture on the history of the yarn industry in the neighborhood. “Attendees are encouraged to bring their projects to work on during this event.” In-person and virtual.

Free, 5 p.m., Historical Society of Pennsylvania, 1300 Locust Street.

KIDS

Parkway Pals

Sister Cities Park brings back its Parkway Pals series of free weekly kids’ programming. On Wednesday mornings, the Academy of Natural Sciences brings its “Investigation Station” to the park.

Free, 10:30-11:30 a.m., Sister Cities Park, 210 North 18th Street.

TALKS

COINTELPRO: A Black August Discussion

UPenn’s Dr. Kelly Harris leads an extensive discussion of the FBI’s secret Counterintelligence Program that targeted African Americans from 1956 to 1971. If you haven’t heard about COINTELPRO, or its local connections, this free discussion will rock your world

Free, 6 p.m., Parkway Central Library, 1901 Vine Street.

MUSIC

The New Pornographers

No matter who’s on stage, Canadian power-pop pop-pop Carl Newman and his ever-popular band of power players constitute an indie-pop supergroup. The New Pornographers dropped their ninth record last year, Continue as a Guest. And now here’s a rare opportunity to see them outdoors! With Gustaf.

$39-$59, 7 p.m., Upper Merion Township Building Park, 175 West Valley Forge Road, King of Prussia.

<a href="https://thenewpornos.bandcamp.com/album/continue-as-a-guest">Continue as a Guest by The New Pornographers</a>

MUSIC

H. Sinno

Following the dissolution of his cult-fave Beirut rock band Mashrou Leila, frontperson Hamed Sinno is on a solo tour performing pieces from their Poems of Consumption song cycle.

$24-$42, 8 p.m., World Cafe Live, 3025 Walnut Street.

MUSIC

Kenny Wayne Shepherd Band

The veteran blues player is touring behind Dirt on My Diamonds Vol 1., released late last year. Just searched “are diamonds machine washable” and it’s not recommended!? The hardest substance on Carth is weak as my fancy thermos?

$49.50-$89.50, 7:30 p.m., Scottish Rite Auditorium, 315 White Horse Pike, Collingswood.

MOVIES

La Haine

Mathieu Kassovitz’s award-winning and influential 1995 offers “24 hours in the lives of three young men in the French suburbs the day after a violent riot” (to quote the IMDB). Stars: Vincent Cassel, Hubert Koundé and Saïd Taghmaoui.

$15.50, 7:30 p.m., Film Society Center, 1412 Chestnut Street.

More Wednesday Stuff

MUSIC: Akai Solo, with QThree, Reek Hellasmoke and gen of the cosmos. $15-$18, 8:30 p.m., Underground Arts, 200 Callowhill Street.

MUSIC: Juan Wauters, with Yung Sham. $15, 7 p.m., Johnny Brenda’s, 1201 North Frankford Avenue.

TRIVIA: Twilight Trivia, hosted by Kirsten Michelle Cills & Kaitlin Pagliaro. Free, 7:30 p.m., City Winery, 990 Filbert Street.

MUSIC: Eve 6, with Tonks. Free, 7:30, Haddon Lake Park, Hillside and South Park avenues, Haddon Heights.

MUSIC: Eric Johnson. $35-$74, 8 p.m., Keswick Theatre, 291 North Keswick Avenue, Glenside.

COMEDY/PODCAST: Ladies and Tangents, with Jeri & Ciara. $31, 8 p.m., Helium, 2031 Sansom Street.

MOVIES: Breakfast at Tiffany’s (Blake Edwards, 1961) $11-$13, 4 & 7 p.m., Ambler Theater, 108 East Butler Avenue, Ambler.

YOGA: Yoga in the Gardens, with Tiffany Searles. $15-$20, 6:30-8:30 p.m., Philadelphia’s Magic Gardens, 1020 South Street.

KIDS: First Wednesday at the Please Touch Museum. $2, 4-7 p.m., 4231 Avenue of the Republic.

THURSDAY, AUGUST 8th

MUSIC

The String Queens

An “authentic, soulful, and orchestral” trio of violinists —Kendall Isadore, Dawn Johnson, and Élise Sharp — from DC, performing baroque, jazz age and modern pop favorites.

$25-$45, 8 p.m., World Cafe Live, 3025 Walnut Street.

ART/SHOPPING

Manayunk Stroll The Street

“Shop, dine, and stroll” in on Thursday nights throughout the summer. June is arts month. July is all about music and August is “pets month.”

Free till you spend money, Thursdays in June, July and August, starts 5 p.m., Main Street, Manayunk.

MUSIC

The Messthetics

This Washington DC instrumental jazz-punk trio — featuring guitarist Anthony Pirog plus Fugazi’s Brendan Canty and Joe Lally — teamed up with saxophonist James Brandon Lewis for an eponymous LP, released in March. The Messthetics and the James Brandon Lewis Trio are both playing Solar Myth on Thursday, and it’s a fair bet they’ll share the stage at some point.

$30.90, 8 p.m., Solar Myth, 1131 South Broad Street.

<a href="https://themessthetics.bandcamp.com/album/the-messthetics-and-james-brandon-lewis">The Messthetics and James Brandon Lewis by The Messthetics</a>

MUSIC

The Connie Club

Adam Wiener (Low Cut Connie) hosts a live music showcase at Ardmore Music Hall, to record segments for his WXPN radio show. This edition features appearances by Bettye Lavette, David Uosikkinen (The Hooters), TaTa Sherise and DJ KAVA.

$35, 8 p.m., Ardmore Music Hall, 23 East Lancaster Avenue.

MUSIC

Beres Hammond

Rising Sun Presents and Jamaican Dave Productions once again present a live show by reggae and lovers rock star Beres Hammond, along with The Exaltations, Da Wolf, Meshia Steele, Luv Smith, Steve Stunner & Reggae Vibration with Peter Blacks.

$59-$149, 7 p.m., Keswick Theatre, 291 North Keswick Avenue, Glenside.

MUSIC

Everclear

The Portland, Oregon band named for high-proof alcohol plays this Recovery Rocks show in Pennsauken, because the world is a complicated place. (Frontman Art Alexakis got clean and sober before founding the band.) Everclear is known for well-known ’90s alt rock songs like “Santa Monica,” “Father of Mine,” “Wonderful” and “Heartspark Dollarsign.”

Free, 8-10 p.m., Jack Curtis Stadium, 5300 North Park Drive, Pennsauken.

MUSIC

Ciara Grace

The Philly singer-songwriter celebrates the release of her debut LP, Write It Down. Ciara Grace has got an arresting voice, judging by this cover of “Sam The Sham & The Pharaohs’ Li’l Red Riding Hood.” With Gina Kaz.

$15-$18, 8 p.m., World Cafe Live, 3025 Walnut Street.

OUTDOORS/SHOPPING

Passyunk Passeggiata

This “Italian-style promenade” features happy hour specials and sidewalk shopping every Thursday over the summer.

Pay as you go, Thursdays, 5-7 p.m., East Passyunk Avenue.

MUSIC

The Isley Brothers and Gladys Knight

Songs you might hear at this show:

“Fight the Power”

“Midnight Train to Georgia”

“That Lady”

“Every Beat of My Heart

“Missing You”

“Between the Sheets”

“Love Overboard”

“This Old Heart of Mine”

“I’ve Got to Use My Imagination”

Can’t argue with that. With Carol Riddick.

$55-$105, 7 p.m., Dell Music Center, 2400 Strawberry Mansion Drive.

MOVIES

Shelley Duvall Double-Feature

Bright Bulb Screening series presents two lesser known films starring the recently departed actress: Bernice Bobs Her Hair (1976, Joan Micklin) and Twilight of the Ice Nymphs (1997, Guy Maddin).

Free, 7 p.m., The Rotunda, 4014 Walnut Street.

MUSIC

Sad Summer Festival

This annual not-that-sad music tour features The Wonder Years, Mayday Parade, The Maine, We the Kings, Real Friends, Knuckle Puck, Hot Milk, Daisy Grenade and Diva Bleach.

$68-$128, 2 p.m., Mann Center, 5201 Parkside Avenue.

More Thursday Stuff

MUSIC: Kam DeLa The Midnight Snack release show, with Rae. Diaz + Ania Hoo. $15, 8 p.m., MilkBoy, 1100 Chestnut Street.

MUSIC: The Chameleons, performing the album Strange Times, with Thieves Among Us and A Cloud of Ravens. $22, 8 p.m., Underground Arts, 200 Callowhill Street.

COMEDY: ShxtsNGigs: Daddy’s Home Tour. Sold out, 7:30 p.m., Fillmore Philly, 29 East Allen Street.

MUSIC: Farmer’s Wife, with Flatwaves and Nave. $15, 8 p.m., PhilaMOCA, 531 North 12th Street.

MUSIC: Plusser, with Laura Hickli and Comprador. Free, 8:30-11:30 p.m., Fringe Bar, 140 North Columbus Boulevard.

MUSIC: Winged Wheel, with Cartoon. $15, 9 p.m., Johnny Brenda’s, 1201 North Frankford Avenue.

MOVIE: Il Bidone (Federico Fellini, 1955), stars Giulietta Masina, Richard Basehart and Broderick Crawford. $15.50, 7:30 p.m., Film Society Center, 1412 Chestnut Street.

FOOD & DRINK: Thirsty Thursday at Bloomsday Cafe. $105, 6 p.m., 414 South 2nd Street.

MUSIC: The Clef Club. Free, 6-7 p.m., Dilworth Park, 1 South 15th Street.

FRIDAY, AUGUST 9th

MUSIC

Green Day

Billie Joe and co. headline the Bank, with support from the Smashing Pumpkins, Rancid, and the Linda Lindas. When Dookie dropped 30 years ago, a Green Day/Rancid show might’ve made some sense, but the Pumpkins? Kinda weird. And the Linda Lindas kids weren’t even born yet. Nonetheless, all the fanbases would’ve crossed over nicely and they probably still do. Get there on time for a stacked bill from top to bottom.

$49-$249, 5:30 p.m., Citizens Bank Park, 1 Citizens Bank Way.

MUSIC/TRIBUTE

Candlelight: A Tribute to Coldplay on Strings

The Listeso String Quartet performs “Clocks,” “Fix You,” “Yellow,” “The Scientist” at another one of their famous candlelit shows.

$54-$75, 6:30 & 9 p.m., the Rittenhouse Hotel, 210 West Rittenhouse Square.

BEER GARDEN

Rodin Garden Bar

Chill out on Fridays all summer long within the confines of this romantic mostly open-air museum on the Parkway devoted to the famous French sculptor.

Free till you spend money, 4-8:30 p.m., Fridays, through August 30th, Rodin Museum, 2151 Benjamin Franklin Parkway.

COMICS/POP CULTURE

Liberty Comic Con

The expo center in Oaks hosts this three-day convention featuring artists, cosplayers, writers, vendors, and live appearances by lots of voice actors like Ryan Bartley, Nadji Jeter, Jill Harris, Dallas Reid and more, from the world of movies, anime, video games, etc.

$20-$30 per day, $65-$75 for the weekend, August 9th-11th, Greater Philadelphia Expo Center, 100 Station Avenue, Oaks.

MUSIC

Sinkane

Gorgeous and groovy rock/funk/jazz.

$20, 7:30 p.m., Kung Fu Necktie, 1248 North Front Street.

DANCE

¡BAILAR en FDR!

This series offers salsa instruction followed by a social dance every other Friday through October 25th in FDR Park’s pretty, open-air Boathouse overlooking the lakes. Hosted by DJ Val Flores & Philly Outdoor Bachata & Salsa.

Free, donations appreciated, dance lesson 7:30-8:30 p.m., social dance 8:30-10:30 p.m., through October 25th, FDR Boathouse, Pattison Avenue & 20th Street.

MUSIC/MINDFULNESS

MindTravel Concert

This isn’t something you see every day, a “live-to-headphones silent piano concert” in a historic graveyard. Composer/pianist Murray Hidary “weaves together music, mindfulness and nature” at this site-specific improvised performance.

$45, 7-9 p.m., Laurel Hill West, 340 Belmont Avenue.

PARTY

Olympia After Hours

For adults looking for a unique night out, Independence Seaport Museum hosts a series of speakeasy evenings in keeping with the historic warship’s Prohibition-era context. The evenings will feature live music, games, themed drinks and more. And, yes, 1920s costumes are encouraged.

$35, 6-9 p.m., 211 South Columbus Boulevard.

DANCE PARTY: Pink Pony Club: Chappell Roan Night. $18.55-$22.70, 9 p.m., Brooklyn Bowl, 1009 Canal Street.

SATURDAY, AUGUST 10th

COMEDY

Ed Bassmaster

The Northeast Philly comedian/Youtuber/prankster just goes around making this city a weirder place. Funnier? More annoying? Not for me to say. But appreciate Ed Bassmaster’s willingness to waste people’s time. Pray you never meet him.

$25-$40, 7:30 p.m., City Winery, 990 Filbert Street.

MOVIES

Matrix Quadrilogy

The Film Society is screening all four of the Wachowskis’ Matrix movies on Saturday. Keep an eye out for all the bent up spoons!

The Matrix (1999) at 11 a.m.

The Matrix Reloaded (2003) at 2:30 p.m.

The Matrix Revolutions (2003) at 6 p.m.

The Matrix Resurrections (2021) at 9 p.m.

$15.50, $40 for the bundle, Film Society Center, 1412 Chestnut Street.

MUSIC

Bhuvana Kannan

The Asian Arts Initiative and Fire Museum Presents presents a Carnatic music concerts by the esteemed veena player. Bhuvana Kannan “is well known for her melodious music, great command over the divine instrument through different slides, gamakas, varying strokes and unique fingering techniques and adherence to tradition.”

$10-$20, 7:30 p.m., Asian Arts Initiative, 1219 Vine Street.

FOOD

Port Richmond Pierogi Festival

This Saturday, join your neighbors at this annual food fest celebrating the noble pierogi, a fried Polish or possibly Chinese pillow filled with potato, cheese, onion, you name it. The Pierogi Festival includes live music, drinks vendors and lots of pierogi to eat. “Pierogies” is also acceptable for the plural.

Free until you buy something, probably pierogi, noon-6 p.m., 2619 East Indiana Avenue.

MUSIC

Iron & Wine

I don’t know about you, but I take comfort in knowin’ Sam Beam’s still out there, takin’ her easy for all us sinners. I don’t like the long hiatuses, but I know Iron & Wine released a record in April called Light Verse. I guess that’s the way the whole durned human comedy keeps perpetuatin’ it-self, down through the generations, westward the wagons, across the sands a time. With Rosali.

$20-$53, 8 p.m., Fillmore Philly, 29 East Allen Street.

BOOKS

Indie Authors Book Fair

Readers and writers are welcome at this free, one-day convention in Oaks featuring exhibits, networking opportunities, workshops, signings and more.

Free, 10 a.m., Greater Philadelphia Expo Center, 100 Station Avenue, Oaks.

MOVIES/PARTICIPATION

The Rocky Horror Picture Show

Historic cemetery Laurel Hill East hosts this screening of the comedy-horror classic presented by Transylvanian Nipple Productions. Note: It’s the pelvic thrust that really drives you insane.

$24.87, 8 p.m., PhilaMOCA, 531 North 12th Street.

MUSIC

Slipknot

With a moniker inspired by the recurring “Slip Nuts” sketches on Conan, this Iowa band is known the world over for their jaunty tunes and fanciful costumes that strike me as irreverent and Chappell Roan-esque. Slipknot’s buddies Knocked Loose and Orbit Culture are joining them on this tour and I bet they all stay up late playing Stardew Valley.

$450-$360, 7 p.m., Mann Center, 5201 Parkside Avenue.

MUSIC

2nd Grade / Jeanines / Lightheaded

A rock solid indie show. Let’s just listen!

<a href="https://areyoufeelinglightheaded.bandcamp.com/album/combustible-gems-2">Combustible Gems by lightheaded</a>

<a href="https://jeanines.bandcamp.com/album/each-day">Each Day by jeanines</a>

<a href="https://2ndgrade.bandcamp.com/album/easy-listening">Easy Listening by 2nd Grade</a>

$15, 8 p.m., Johnny Brenda’s, 1201 North Frankford Avenue.

CARS/HEARSES

Annual Classic Hearse Show

Laurel Hill East hosts this offbeat car show featuring coffin cruisers, ambulances, flower cars and limousines. BYO, if you please.

Pay what you want, 10 a.m.-4 p.m., Laurel Hill East, 3822 Ridge Avenue.

DANCE PARTY

Making Time

Dave P. hosts a free night of good music and transcendental vibes at Bok.

Free, 6-11 p.m., Bok Bar, 800 Mifflin Street.

MUSIC

Jess Cornelius

This captivating guitar-pop yowie originally hails from Oceania. Now based in L.A., the ex-Teeth & Tongue frontperson just released CARE/TAKING under her own name, and it’s stylish, thoughtful and often very, very catchy. With Grace Vonderkuhn.

$16, 8:30 p.m., MilkBoy, 1100 Chestnut Street.

SUNDAY, AUGUST 11th

COMEDY/MUSIC

Fred Armisen: Comedy For Musicians But Everyone Is Welcome

Imagine the climactic prom scene in Carrie, except instead of fire, everybody’s trapped in a room where Fred Armisen is doing his drummer character. JK if it makes you happy it can’t be that bad.

$48-$89, 7 p.m., Fillmore Philly, 29 East Allen Street.

MUSIC

Inspectah Deck

The Wu Tang Clan alum plays City Winery with Dell-P & DJ Kirsh. Inspectah Deck is also a member of Czarface, who last year released Czartificial Intelligence. Other Czarface album titles include Czarmageddon and The Odd Czar Against Us. Here’s a freebie: Mic Czar’d Lemonade.

$40-$60, 7:30 p.m., City Winery, 990 Filbert Street.

DRINKS/DRAWING

Return to Goth Summer Camp

Dr. Sketchy’s “anti-art school” presents an afternoon of live model drawing with beer and music. “Grab your art supplies and get ready to draw the stunning goth campers (and camp counselor).”

$15-$20, noon-3 p.m., Arch Enemy Arts, 109 Arch Street.

MOVIES

All About Lily Chou Chou

A rare screening of Shunji Iwai’s 2001 crime/romance favorite about teenager with tumultuous lives seeking solace in the music of a pop star. Tagline: “If you scream and no one hears you, she’s there for you.” Also, you might be in space.

$14.93, 7 p.m., PhilaMOCA, 531 North 12th Street.

MUSIC/OUTDOORS

Sounds of Summer

This edition of the Fairmount Park Conservatory’s Second Sunday Concert Series includes music Luke Carlos O’Reilly featuring Tyreek McDole, with MIC’d Up. Plus food trucks and activities for the kids. BYO blankets and lawn chairs.

Free, 5-8 p.m., Parkside Edge, Parkside Avenue between East and West Memorial Hall Drives.

FESTIVAL/MUSIC/BIKES

Ardmore Rock N’ Ride: Outdoor Music Festival and Bike Race

Live music on two stages by Rebirth Brass Band, Octave Cat, Yellowman, Stella Ruze, Remember Jones, Omar’s Hat, Marielle Kraft and Johnny Shortcake. Proceeds benefit Narberth Ambulance.

Free, noon, Ardmore Music Hall, 23 East Lancaster Avenue.

FESTIVAL

“Unapologetic” Summer Festival

“A unique celebration created to honor and support women from all walks of life.” Not a lot of details have been announced yet, the site promised all-female live entertainment, an all-female marketplace, inspiring speakers,” “brand activations” and more.

$30-$50, 2-8 p.m., Liberty Point, 211 South Christopher Columbus Boulevard.
